frames.processing

Class Shape

  • java.lang.Object
    • frames.core.Frame
      • frames.processing.Shape

  • public class Shape
extends Frame
    A shape is a Frame specialization that should always be attached to a scene (see Frame.isAttached(Graph)) and that can be set from a retained-mode rendering Processing PShape or from an immediate-mode rendering Processing procedure. Either case the shape is split in two a front and a back shape. The front shape will be used for rendering and the back shape for picking with exact precision by default, see Frame.setPrecision(Precision). When picking a shape it will be highlighted according to a highlighting policy, see setHighlighting(Highlighting).

    Picking in an exact manner is costly. If performance is a concern, use a Frame.precision() different than Precision#EXACT or a simpler representation for the back shape.

    Retained mode

    To set a retained-mode shape call setGraphics(PShape) which will set both the front and the back shape to be the same pshape. Call setFrontGraphics(PShape) and setFrontGraphics(PShape) to set different graphics for rendering and picking, respectively.

    Immediate mode

    To set an immediate-mode shape override setGraphics(PGraphics) which will set both the front and the back shape to be the same graphics procedure. Override setFrontGraphics(PGraphics) and setFrontGraphics(PGraphics) to set different graphics procedures for rendering and picking, respectively.

    Picking

    Picking a shape is done according to a precision which can either be: Precision#FIXED, Precision#ADAPTIVE or Precision#EXACT. Refer to the Frame documentation for both, Precision#FIXED and Precision#ADAPTIVE. The default Precision#EXACT precision use ray-casting of the pointer device over the projected pixels of the back shape. To set a different precision, use Frame.setPrecision(Precision). See also Frame.precision().

    Highlighting

    The shape may be highlighted when picking takes place according to a highlighting() policy as follows:
    1. Shape.Highlighting.NONE: no highlighting takes place.
    2. Shape.Highlighting.FRONT: the front-shape (see setFrontGraphics(PShape) and setFrontGraphics(PGraphics)) is scaled by a 1.15 factor.
    3. Shape.Highlighting.BACK: the back-shape (see setBackGraphics(PShape) and setBackGraphics(PGraphics)) is displayed instead of the front-shape.
    4. Shape.Highlighting.FRONT_BACK: both, the front and the back shapes are displayed. The back shape is made translucent

    Default is Shape.Highlighting.FRONT. Set the policy with setHighlighting(Highlighting)).

      • setHighlighting

        public void setHighlighting(Shape.Highlighting highlighting)
        Highlights the shape when picking takes place as follows:
        1. Shape.Highlighting.NONE: no highlighting takes place.
        2. Shape.Highlighting.FRONT: the front-shape (see setFrontGraphics(PShape) and setFrontGraphics(PGraphics)) is scaled by a 1.15 factor.
        3. Shape.Highlighting.BACK: the back-shape (see setBackGraphics(PShape) and setBackGraphics(PGraphics)) is displayed instead of the front-shape.
        4. Shape.Highlighting.FRONT_BACK: both, the front and the back shapes are displayed. The back shape is made translucent

        Default is Shape.Highlighting.FRONT.

        See Also:
        highlighting()

      • highlighting

        public Shape.Highlighting highlighting()
        Returns the highlighting mode.
        See Also:
        setHighlighting(Highlighting)

      • setPrecision

        public void setPrecision(Frame.Precision precision)
        Description copied from class: Frame
        Sets the frame picking precision.

        When Frame.precision() is Frame.Precision.FIXED or Frame.Precision.ADAPTIVE Picking is done by checking if the pointer lies within a squared area around the frame Frame.position() screen projection which size is defined by Frame.setPrecisionThreshold(float).

        When Frame.precision() is Frame.Precision.EXACT, picking is done in a precise manner according to the projected pixels of the visual representation related to the frame. It is meant to be implemented by derived classes (providing the means attach a visual representation to the frame) and requires the graph to implement a back buffer.

        Default implementation of this policy will behave like Frame.Precision.FIXED.

        Overrides:
        setPrecision in class Frame
        See Also:
        Frame.precision(), Frame.setPrecisionThreshold(float), Frame.precisionThreshold()

      • visit

        public void visit()
        Description copied from class: Frame
        Procedure called on the frame by the graph traversal algorithm. Default implementation is empty, i.e., it is meant to be implemented by derived classes. Only meaningful if the frame is attached to a graph.

        Hierarchical culling, i.e., culling of the frame and its children, should be decided here. Set the culling flag with Frame.cull(boolean) according to your culling condition: 

         
 frame = new Frame(graph) {
   public void visit() {
     // Hierarchical culling is optional and disabled by default. When the cullingCondition
     // (which should be implemented by you) is true, scene.traverse() will prune the branch
     // at the frame
     cull(cullingCondition);
     if(!isCulled())
       // Draw your object here, in the local coordinate system.
   }
 }
        Overrides:
        visit in class Frame
        See Also:
        Graph.traverse(), Frame.cull(boolean), Frame.isCulled()

      • draw

        public void draw()
        Same as draw(graph().frontBuffer()). Use it instead of Scene.traverse().
        See Also:
        Scene.traverse(), draw(PGraphics)

      • draw

        public void draw(PGraphics pGraphics)
        Draws the shape into the pGraphics. Use it instead of Scene.traverse(PGraphics) (which in turn calls it) such as: 
         
 void draw() {
   pGraphics.pushMatrix();
   // apply the local shape transformation before drawing
   Scene.applyTransformation(pGraphics, shape);
   // or apply the global shape transformation
   //Scene.applyWorldTransformation(pGraphics, shape);
   shape.draw(pGraphics);
   pGraphics.popMatrix();
 }
        See Also:
        Scene.traverse(PGraphics), draw()

      • setGraphics

        public void setGraphics(PShape shape)
        Sets the retained mode pshape for both, the front and the back shapes.
        See Also:
